the idea is then to start bringing those other skill sets up to championship level,

Can you elaborate on on what that looks like and say maybe, like tell us what you do, but maybe how you would recommend that to someone who's not at your level coming up lower belt, how they could start to develop the mental side of the game.
Sure. So I'm going to go out first and sort of trash a little bit, a common saying that's use in Giu-Tzu where people just say, oh, just show up.

Just showing up is the bare fucking minimum that anyone can actually do. Like if you're like, you know, people say, oh, like to get good, like just show up. It's like, no, no, no, like anyone can just show up.

The guys that aren't just showing up, they're not doing Giu-Tzu. So what do you care about what they're doing? Like, like, they, but, you know, if you're doing Giu-Tzu, I mean, you're already showing up. Like, like, showing up is the fucking minimum. And I hate this expression because like, that's just like same. Just wake up. Yeah, exactly.

Like, but it's like anyone can do that. Like, just by virtue of being in Giu-Tzu, you're like, you're showing up anyway. You can't just do something that just absolutely anyone can do and expect to get a better result than these other guys. Like, like, it's, it's just doesn't work like that.

I think you need to come into training each day with the intention of being mindful. I think for people that want to come into training and they want to start developing more the, like, the, like, mental training for Giu-Tzu, I would start off with just taking notes on what you covered in that, like, like what you're coach covered in that class.

I don't think that you need to take in depth notes. Like, I think people, they start like writing long hand and they're starting to write essays to describe the techniques. I don't think you have to go that far. Like, I, I certainly don't write very, very detailed notes in terms of what I'm working on and what I'm drilling. I would take more detailed notes if there's a particular point that I want to emphasize about a particular technique that I'm working on. But really, this is where having a language developer, I think, I'm going to be able to do that.

I've got, or, you know, jargon developed for the techniques that you're using. So I know, like, a lot of people will give, say, John Danah, her criticism for, you know, his extreme use of Japanese terms and mixing it with English, which I think is fair criticism.
But the point is, is that we, you need to have some sort of language that you're using to describe each technique that you're applying. So that way you can just take notes on these things.
So what I would suggest is to take short hand notes on what your coach has covered in that class. The idea then is that your coach teaches you a technique.
You maybe did some drilling on it. And that might be, you know, if you're just showing up, that's the only time you got to see that technique.
But you go home, you get a pen and paper and you start writing down what was covered in class. You're now mentally working through for a second time those exact same techniques.
I think I was talking to a teammate about this the other day. This even study that shows that you will get a committing something to long term memory.
When you take notes, if you use pen and paper, it is easy to commit it to long term memory than if you were trying to type things down on a phone.
So I think like those are other little things that you can add in as well.
I always felt that was the case. It's anecdotally from my own experience from school and things like this. So I've always preferred to go pen and paper.
I know some people are typing on their notes, but I believe there's some research suggesting that, you know, actually physically writing it down allows you to commit it to memory a little bit better.
Yeah. I strongly agree with that. We're discussing pens before the show. And yeah, I definitely think that pen to paper is key for whether it's digital techniques or it's journalist.
It's like telling your gratitude, whatever it's like do it the old school way.
And so then going beyond that. So that was a very long winded way of me going about explaining, just take some notes on class.

But then the idea is that if you want it to go beyond that, especially if you're not sure where to take your actual training is to start trying to find match footage of the positions that your coach would have been covering in class and try and look and see how those positions play out and look at what other high level competitors are doing in the same city.

And so I think that's the way I think about the situations trying to find like trying to sort of see what the different options are, how people are reacting, how they're sort of counter reacting in these different situations.
Now, if you don't know how to find match footage on specific positions, then that's fine. You can also just go ahead and like pick a competitor you like and just watch a little bit of what he does.
You know, watch it even if it's not what your coach is showing necessarily watching match footage of a particular competitor and watching what he does in repeat scenarios.

Like we were talking about Gordon Ryan before. Let's say every single time Gordon Ryan plays half guard. He doesn't do this. But let's say like every time Gordon Ryan plays half guard, he chooses to claim an underhook.
You can look at, you know, okay, how is he claiming the underhook each time when he does take an underhook. What is he generally trying to look for first as he is first sort of major technique.

What are the common reactions he's getting off of that and how is he reacting to those reactions. And then the idea is that you can start just looking at this and even taking notes on it or even if you don't take notes, just watching it and trying to at least observe what he's doing and trying to take it on board.

There was a stage in my competition career where I discovered that if you're applying an outside hill hook and you allowed the ankle to break generally what happened was is that it actually released a tremendous amount of tension in the lock and then it would allow the person to escape.

So I know a lot of times you know people will practice hill hooks say for it and you'll think oh yeah you know like if a target the ankle that's okay too because that's just another thing that you're going to break but I actually found that as a result of breaking the ankle it would actually allow people to get out of the hill hook so and you know a lot of people are willing like even relatively low competition like relatively low level competition people are willing to suffer ankle injuries but not knee injuries.
